questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She recently moved to a new city. Her father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 46 years. Her paternal uncle died because of small bowel cancer. Her paternal grandfather died because of stomach cancer. Current medications include esomeprazole and a multivitamin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years but quit 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy is unremarkable. Germline testing via DNA sequencing in this patient shows mutations in DNA repair genes MLH1 and MSH2. Which of the following will this patient most likely require at some point in her life?

choices.text: Surgical removal of a desmoid tumor
Annual measurement of carcinoembryonic antigen and CA 19-9

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common extracolonic malignancy associated with Lynch syndrome is endometrial cancer. Female patients with Lynch syndrome have a ∼ 40% lifetime risk of developing endometrial cancer, with most cases occurring in premenopausal women. Lynch syndrome is also associated with an increased lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer (∼ 10%). Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy at the end of childbearing age (∼ 40 years) is therefore recommended. In addition, women with Lynch syndrome should receive annual pelvic examination with transvaginal ultrasonography and endometrial biopsy starting at the age of 30–35 years. Patients with Lynch syndrome should also undergo annual colonoscopy beginning at 20–25 years of age to screen for colorectal cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmoid tumors are an extracolonic manifestation of Gardner syndrome. If the tumor is symptomatic and resectable, surgical excision with a tumor free margin is the treatment of choice; desmoid tumors are locally aggressive in nature and carry a risk of local recurrence. Patients with Gardner syndrome would already have polyps on colonoscopy by adolescence, however, and germline testing would show a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene.

C) INCORRECT:

A pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy is a surgical option for pancreatic carcinomas located in the pancreatic head. While pancreatic cancer has been found to be associated with Lynch syndrome in rare cases, another malignancy that necessitates a different form of management is much more commonly associated with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilateral prophylactic mastectomy is a risk-reducing surgery offered to women with a high lifetime risk of developing breast cancer (e.g., those with a BRCA mutation). Currently, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that individuals with Lynch syndrome have an increased lifetime risk of developing breast cancer, making bilateral prophylactic mastectomy inappropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic subtotal or total proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis is recommended in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). A family history of gastrointestinal malignancy is also seen in FAP. However, patients with FAP would have numerous polyps on colonoscopy by adolescence, and germline testing would show a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene rather than in MLH1 and MSH2. Patients with Lynch syndrome are at high risk of gastrointestinal malignancies and should receive an annual colonoscopy beginning at 20–25 years of age to screen for colorectal cancer, but prophylactic proctocolectomy is not recommended.

F) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and CA 19-9 are tumor markers for colorectal and endometrial cancers. CEA and CA 19-9 are mainly tested to monitor treatment response and to detect tumor recurrence (by recording the rise/fall of tumor markers) if levels are elevated at cancer diagnosis. Although individuals with Lynch syndrome show an increased risk of developing these malignancies, screening with CEA and CA 19-9 is not done because they are neither specific nor sensitive enough.
questions.hint: This woman has three family members with gastrointestinal cancers in two different generations, and one relative was under the age of 50 when diagnosed (3-2-1 rule). These findings fulfill the Amsterdam II criteria for Lynch syndrome, which is caused by mutations in various DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2).

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Germline mutations in the MLH1 gene result in defective DNA mismatch repair, the underlying cause of Lynch syndrome, which is the most common hereditary form of colorectal cancer. Patients with Lynch syndrome most often have right-sided colon cancers that are diagnosed at a relatively young age (< 50 years old). It is also associated with gastric and endometrial cancer (as seen in this patient's family), as well as ovarian cancer and urothelial cancer. Screening colonoscopy may show a limited number of polyps (usually < 10) or poorly-differentiated tumor growth, as seen in this patient. Other DNA mismatch repair genes include MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

Patients with Lynch syndrome should undergo aggressive screening, which includes annual colonoscopy, pelvic examination for women, and upper endoscopy starting at an early age.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the TP53 gene, which encodes p53, is the underlying defect that causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Affected patients typically develop sarcomas, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and/or adrenocortical carcinoma. Mutation of the TP53 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of Lynch syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the DCC gene is responsible for the development of colon cancer. However, it is not linked to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the KRAS gene is linked to the development of colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer, not to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the APC gene causes familial adenomatous polyposis. Affected patients have hundreds of colonic polyps that develop in childhood. These can develop into colorectal cancer, often at an early age. However, FAP does not predispose to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which is more commonly seen in patients with Lynch syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's family fulfills the 3-2-1 rule of Lynch syndrome: cancer in 3 affected family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and increased straining during defecation for 3 months. During this time, he has lost 5 kg (11 lb) despite no change in appetite. He has a family history of colon cancer in his maternal uncle and maternal grandfather. His mother died of ovarian cancer at the age of 46 years. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, hematocrit is 34%, and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the resected mass shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the MSH2 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene APC. Affected individuals have hundreds of colonic polyps that typically develop in the second and third decades of life. The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is 100% by 45 years of age. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation and lack of polyps on colonoscopy are inconsistent with FAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the p53 tumor suppressor gene. Subsequent loss of heterozygosity results in the development of multiple malignancies (e.g., sarcomas, adrenal gland and breast cancer, leukemia) at an early age. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation is consistent with a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Turcot syndrome is a variant of either familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk for colorectal cancer as well as malignant CNS tumors (e.g., medulloblastoma with FAP, glioma with Lynch syndrome). Although MSH2 mutations can be found in patients with Turcot syndrome, lack of evidence of a CNS tumor in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene. PJS manifests with multiple hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract (predominantly in the jejunum) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation of the lips, buccal mucosas, palms, and soles. Individuals with PJS have an increased risk for colorectal cancer (∼ 40% lifetime risk) as well as for extraintestinal cancers (e.g., ovarian, breast, pancreatic cancer). This patient's MSH2 gene mutation, lack of polyps on colonoscopy, and absence of mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation are inconsistent with PJS.

E) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the tumor suppressor gene APC. Gardner syndrome is characterized by the presence of hundreds of colonic polyps together with bony and/or soft tissue tumors (e.g., osteomas, desmoid tumors, lipomas, fibromas). The lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer is 100%. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation, lack of polyps on colonoscopy, and absence of extracolonic bony and/or soft tissue tumors are inconsistent with Gardner syndrome.

F) CORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is a familial cancer syndrome caused by autosomal dominant mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MSH2, MLH1). Individuals with this syndrome have an ∼ 80% lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer (typically in the proximal colon). While genetic testing is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis, the family history-based Amsterdam II criteria can be used to identify individuals who are likely to be affected (3-2-1 rule: Lynch syndrome-associated cancer in ≥ 3 family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age). This patient fulfills the Amsterdam II criteria.
questions.hint: Mutations in the MSH2 DNA mismatch repair gene lead to microsatellite instability. In addition to having an increased risk of colorectal cancer, individuals with this mutation are more likely to develop other cancers such as endometrial, ovarian, and gastric carcinomas.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man was admitted for a bowel obstruction and found to have a large obstructing colonic adenocarcinoma just proximal to the hepatic flexure. He underwent a successful right hemicolectomy. Pathology was consistent with an obstructing, 9-cm colon adenocarcinoma, with no evidence of lymph node involvement in 17 sampled nodes.
When asked about his family history, the patient states that his mother and maternal aunt were diagnosed with endometrial cancer at ages 56 and 59, respectively. His mother has no other siblings, but her father died in his early 40s of an unknown cause after several months of worsening abdominal pain and weight loss. The patient has two younger siblings and three children, all of whom are healthy.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by the development of gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps; the development of small, dark-colored spots on the lips, around and inside the mouth, near the eyes and nostrils, and around the anus; and an increased risk for cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, cervix, ovary, and breast.

B) INCORRECT:

BRCA mutations are associated with premature breast and ovarian cancers and, to a lesser extent, pancreatic and prostate cancers.

C) CORRECT:

There are two principal inherited colorectal cancer syndromes: familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; also known as Lynch syndrome). This patient’s history of a large right-sided colon cancer, in combination with his family history of endometrial cancer, strongly suggests HNPCC.

Compared with FAP, HNPCC usually causes larger, less-aggressive right-sided colon cancers. When systemic treatment is needed, HNPCC colon tumors are thought to be more responsive to chemotherapy than FAP tumors. HNPCC also causes endometrial cancer and, to a lesser extent, cancers of the ovary, stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, brain, and upper uroepithelial tract.

Key learning point: Other than colorectal cancer, the most common cancer associated with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) is endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with breast cancer, sarcoma, brain tumors, and leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

FAP tends to cause aggressive distal colonic lesions in a background of colonic polyposis and also predisposes patients to duodenal polyps, gastric cancer, and abdominal desmoid tumors.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman presents for postoperative follow-up after a hemicolectomy with regional lymphadenectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon.
Three months ago, she reported episodes of bright-red blood from her rectum. Colonoscopy at that time revealed a 3.2-cm ulcerated mass in the ascending colon, with no other colorectal abnormalities. Imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no regional lymphadenopathy or distant metastases. Pathology revealed a 3.4-cm, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion only into the muscularis propria. None of the 20 tested lymph nodes were positive for metastatic disease.
Her brother, mother, and maternal aunt were all diagnosed with colon cancer in their thirties.
Other than colorectal cancer, which one of the following cancers poses the greatest lifetime risk for this patient?

choices.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s personal and family history are suggestive of Lynch syndrome (also called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer), an autosomal dominant condition caused by germline mutations in the DNA mismatch repair system.

According to the revised Amsterdam criteria, all of the following criteria must be met for a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome:

• ≥3 relatives with Lynch syndrome-associated cancers (most commonly colorectal or endometrial)
• One affected person is a first-degree relative of the other two
• ≥2 successive generations affected
• ≥1 relative diagnosed before age 50
• Tumors confirmed on pathology
• Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded

Colorectal cancer is the most common cancer in patients with Lynch syndrome, with a lifetime risk of approximately 70%. Colonic adenocarcinomas in these patients are most often located in the proximal colon and splenic flexure. Extracolonic cancers are also seen, and endometrial carcinoma is the most common, with a lifetime risk of approximately 40% to 50%. Other potential sites of malignancy include the stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, ovaries, ureter, renal pelvis, and brain.

Given the increased risk of endometrial and ovarian cancer, women with Lynch syndrome should be educated on the symptoms of these cancers and be evaluated promptly if such symptoms develop. There is no proven strategy for preventing or screening for these cancers. Although pelvic ultrasound and blood levels of cancer antigen 125 have been suggested as screening modalities for ovarian cancer, they have limited utility because of low sensitivity and specificity. On the other hand, screening for endometrial cancer with annual endometrial biopsy every 1 to 2 years starting at age 30 to 35 is quite sensitive and specific and can therefore be reasonably considered according to guidelines from the National Comprehensive Cancer Network and the Cancer Genetic Studies Consortium. Finally, some women may choose to proceed with a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy to reduce their risk for both endometrial and ovarian cancer. The timing of this procedure can be individualized to the woman’s specific risk profile and reproductive plans.

Key learning point: The most common extracolonic type of cancer seen in women with Lynch syndrome is endometrial cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is not one of the cancers most commonly associated with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with adrenal cortical carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with osteosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman who is otherwise well reports a 2-day history of hematuria. She underwent menopause 13 years ago.
Her father was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 49, and her grandfather died from colon cancer in his sixth decade. She has three sisters, one with a history of ovarian cancer and another with a history of endometrial cancer.
Results of a complete blood count, coagulation studies, and kidney function tests are all within normal limits. Urinalysis shows >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2). No casts or dysmorphic red cells are noted.
What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hematuria may be caused by abnormalities in the urologic tract from the glomeruli to the urethra, and evaluation should include a detailed history to help prioritize the evaluation.

In this case, the family history of cancer is of great concern, because it is highly suggestive of Lynch syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome that is characterized by an increased risk for cancer of the upper urologic tract, as well as cancers of the colon, endometrium, ovaries, small bowel, bile duct, pancreas, skin, and brain. Lynch syndrome is diagnosed on the basis of the Amsterdam II criteria (≥3 affected members in the family, involving ≥2 generations in which ≥1 cancer is diagnosed before age 50).

Although evaluation of microscopic hematuria is guided by the patient’s risk for urothelial carcinoma, evaluation of persistent gross hematuria (in the absence of features to suggest intrinsic renal disease such as dysmorphic erythrocytes, elevated creatinine levels, or significant proteinuria) should always include imaging of both the upper urinary tract (with CT urography) and the lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy). CT urography should generally precede cystoscopy — and is especially important to prioritize in a patient with concern for Lynch syndrome, which specifically increases the risk for upper urinary tract cancers. If any upper urinary tract findings are noted on CT urography, they will be endoscopically evaluated (and potentially biopsied) in the operating room; during this evaluation, the lower urinary tract can also be visualized, sparing the patient a redundant office cystoscopy procedure.

Key learning point: All patients presenting with gross hematuria should be evaluated with CT urography (followed by cystoscopy) to rule out malignancy; this is particularly important for patients with Lynch syndrome who are at increased risk for urothelial carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is less sensitive than CT at detecting small, solid lesions and is therefore typically not a recommended imaging modality for the upper urinary tract in high-risk patients such as this one.

C) INCORRECT:

Although evaluation of microscopic hematuria is guided by the patient’s risk for urothelial carcinoma, evaluation of persistent gross hematuria (in the absence of features to suggest intrinsic renal disease such as dysmorphic erythrocytes, elevated creatinine levels, or significant proteinuria) should always include imaging of both the upper urinary tract (with CT urography) and the lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy). CT urography should generally precede cystoscopy — and is especially important to prioritize in a patient with concern for Lynch syndrome, which specifically increases the risk for upper urinary tract cancers. If any upper urinary tract findings are noted on CT urography, they will be endoscopically evaluated (and potentially biopsied) in the operating room; during this evaluation, the lower urinary tract can also be visualized, sparing the patient a redundant office cystoscopy procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology is not sufficiently sensitive and is therefore not recommended as part of the algorithm for evaluating hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography could be considered if the patient had abnormal uterine bleeding.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents for postoperative follow-up after a hemicolectomy with regional lymphadenectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. Three months ago, a colonoscopy at that time revealed a 3.2-cm ulcerated mass in the ascending colon, with no other colorectal abnormalities. Pathology revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion only into the muscularis propria. Her brother, mother, and maternal aunt were all diagnosed with colon cancer in their thirties. Other than colorectal cancer, this patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

According to the revised Amsterdam criteria, all of the following criteria must be met for a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome:

• ≥3 relatives with Lynch syndrome-associated cancers (most commonly colorectal or endometrial)
• One affected person is a first-degree relative of the other two
• ≥2 successive generations affected
• ≥1 relative diagnosed before age 50
• Tumors confirmed on pathology
• Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded

Colorectal cancer is the most common cancer in patients with Lynch syndrome, with a lifetime risk of approximately 70%. Colonic adenocarcinomas in these patients are most often located in the proximal colon and splenic flexure. Extracolonic cancers are also seen, and endometrial carcinoma is the most common, with a lifetime risk of approximately 40% to 50%. Other potential sites of malignancy include the stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, ovaries, ureter, renal pelvis, and brain.

Given the increased risk of endometrial and ovarian cancer, women with Lynch syndrome should be educated on the symptoms of these cancers and be evaluated promptly if such symptoms develop. There is no proven strategy for preventing or screening for these cancers. Although pelvic ultrasound and blood levels of cancer antigen 125 have been suggested as screening modalities for ovarian cancer, they have limited utility because of low sensitivity and specificity. On the other hand, screening for endometrial cancer with annual endometrial biopsy every 1 to 2 years starting at age 30 to 35 is quite sensitive and specific and can therefore be reasonably considered according to guidelines from the National Comprehensive Cancer Network and the Cancer Genetic Studies Consortium. Finally, some women may choose to proceed with a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy to reduce their risk for both endometrial and ovarian cancer. The timing of this procedure can be individualized to the woman’s specific risk profile and reproductive plans.

Key learning point: The most common extracolonic type of cancer seen in women with Lynch syndrome is endometrial cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is not one of the cancers most commonly associated with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with adrenal cortical carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with osteosarcoma.
questions.hint: This patient’s personal and family history are suggestive of Lynch syndrome (also called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer), an autosomal dominant condition caused by germline mutations in the DNA mismatch repair system.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of fatigue and increased straining during defecation. He has unintentionally lost 5 kg during this period, with no change in appetite. His family history is notable for colon cancer in his maternal uncle and maternal grandfather, and his mother died of ovarian cancer at age 46. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 112 g/L (125–170), hematocrit of 0.34 L/L (0.38–0.50), and mean corpuscular volume of 76 fL (80–100). Colonoscopy reveals an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathology of the resected mass shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis identifies a mutation in the MSH2 gene. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the p53 tumor suppressor gene. Subsequent loss of heterozygosity results in the development of multiple malignancies (e.g., sarcomas, adrenal gland and breast cancer, leukemia) at an early age. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation is consistent with a different condition.

B) CORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is a familial cancer syndrome caused by autosomal dominant mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MSH2, MLH1). Individuals with this syndrome have an ∼ 80% lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer (typically in the proximal colon). While genetic testing is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis, the family history-based Amsterdam II criteria can be used to identify individuals who are likely to be affected (3-2-1 rule: Lynch syndrome-associated cancer in ≥ 3 family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age). This patient fulfills the Amsterdam II criteria.

Key learning point: Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MSH2) and is associated with a high risk of early-onset colorectal and other cancers.

C) INCORRECT:

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene APC. Affected individuals have hundreds of colonic polyps that typically develop in the second and third decades of life. The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is 100% by 45 years of age. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation and lack of polyps on colonoscopy are inconsistent with FAP.

D) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene. PJS manifests with multiple hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract (predominantly in the jejunum) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation of the lips, buccal mucosas, palms, and soles. Individuals with PJS have an increased risk for colorectal cancer (∼ 40% lifetime risk) as well as for extraintestinal cancers (e.g., ovarian, breast, pancreatic cancer). This patient's MSH2 gene mutation, lack of polyps on colonoscopy, and absence of mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation are inconsistent with PJS.

E) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the tumor suppressor gene APC. Gardner syndrome is characterized by the presence of hundreds of colonic polyps together with bony and/or soft tissue tumors (e.g., osteomas, desmoid tumors, lipomas, fibromas). The lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer is 100%. This patient's MSH2 gene mutation, lack of polyps on colonoscopy, and absence of extracolonic bony and/or soft tissue tumors are inconsistent with Gardner syndrome.
questions.hint: Mutations in the MSH2 DNA mismatch repair gene lead to microsatellite instability. In addition to having an increased risk of colorectal cancer, individuals with this mutation are more likely to develop other cancers such as endometrial, ovarian, and gastric carcinomas.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic for postoperative follow-up after undergoing a hemicolectomy with regional lymphadenectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. Three months ago, colonoscopy revealed a 3.2-cm ulcerated mass in the ascending colon, with no other colorectal abnormalities. Pathology showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion limited to the muscularis propria. Her brother, mother, and maternal aunt were all diagnosed with colon cancer in their thirties. Other than colorectal cancer, you recognize that this patient is at increased risk for which one of the following conditions?

choices.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with osteosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with adrenal cortical carcinoma.

C) CORRECT:

According to the revised Amsterdam criteria, all of the following criteria must be met for a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome:

• ≥3 relatives with Lynch syndrome-associated cancers (most commonly colorectal or endometrial)
• One affected person is a first-degree relative of the other two
• ≥2 successive generations affected
• ≥1 relative diagnosed before age 50
• Tumors confirmed on pathology
• Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded

Colorectal cancer is the most common cancer in patients with Lynch syndrome, with a lifetime risk of approximately 70%. Colonic adenocarcinomas in these patients are most often located in the proximal colon and splenic flexure. Extracolonic cancers are also seen, and endometrial carcinoma is the most common, with a lifetime risk of approximately 40% to 50%. Other potential sites of malignancy include the stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, ovaries, ureter, renal pelvis, and brain.

Given the increased risk of endometrial and ovarian cancer, women with Lynch syndrome should be educated on the symptoms of these cancers and be evaluated promptly if such symptoms develop. There is no proven strategy for preventing or screening for these cancers. Although pelvic ultrasound and blood levels of cancer antigen 125 have been suggested as screening modalities for ovarian cancer, they have limited utility because of low sensitivity and specificity. On the other hand, screening for endometrial cancer with annual endometrial biopsy every 1 to 2 years starting at age 30 to 35 is quite sensitive and specific and can therefore be reasonably considered according to guidelines from the National Comprehensive Cancer Network and the Cancer Genetic Studies Consortium. Finally, some women may choose to proceed with a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy to reduce their risk for both endometrial and ovarian cancer. The timing of this procedure can be individualized to the woman’s specific risk profile and reproductive plans.

Key learning point: The most common extracolonic type of cancer seen in women with Lynch syndrome is endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is not commonly associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is not one of the cancers most commonly associated with Lynch syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient’s personal and family history are suggestive of Lynch syndrome (also called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer), an autosomal dominant condition caused by germline mutations in the DNA mismatch repair system.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician with intermenstrual bleeding and heavy menses for the past 4 months. She does not take any medications. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 42 years. A curettage sample shows dysplastic tall, columnar, cells in the endometrium without intervening stroma. Germline sequencing shows a mutation in the MLH1 gene. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of neoplasia in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to excise bulky DNA adducts
Instability of short tandem DNA repeats
Impaired repair of deaminated DNA bases

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The accumulation of double-stranded DNA breaks is associated with BRCA+ breast cancers and Fanconi anemia (due to defects in homologous end joining) as well as ataxia telangiectasia (due to defects in nonhomologous end joining). These defects are not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective checkpoint control is associated with mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene and leads to unrestrained division of cells. This is the underlying defect of Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome associated with sarcoma, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and adrenocortical carcinoma. This condition is not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

C) INCORRECT:

The inability to excise bulky DNA adducts is the key defect in nucleotide excision repair. This is the underlying defect of xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition in which cells cannot repair the pyrimidine dimers that form after ultraviolet light exposure. Xeroderma pigmentosum manifests with dry skin, photosensitivity, and early skin cancers. This condition is not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

D) CORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is associated with instability of short tandem DNA repeats (microsatellites) due to germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2, and MSH6). Patients with Lynch syndrome have an increased lifetime risk for multiple malignancies including colorectal, endometrial, gastric, urothelial, and ovarian cancers.

E) INCORRECT:

Base excision repair replaces deaminated DNA bases throughout the cell cycle. Defects in base excision repair are associated with some forms of familial colorectal cancer but are not associated with endometrial cancer or the MLH1 gene.
questions.hint: The features of intermenstrual bleeding, heavy menses, and histopathologic dysplasia of the endometrium suggest a diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma. In a young woman with a family history of colorectal cancer at a young age, these features raise suspicion for a hereditary cancer syndrome. The presence of a mutated MLH1 gene confirms a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome.
